xyz.acygn.mokapot

Class ClassKnowledge<T>

  • java.lang.Object
    • xyz.acygn.mokapot.ClassKnowledge<T>
  • Type Parameters:
    T - The class which this class knowledge is about.
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    ArrayKnowledge, CopiableKnowledge, InterfaceKnowledge, LambdaKnowledge, NonCopiableKnowledge, UnmarshallableKnowledge

    public abstract class ClassKnowledge<T>
extends Object
    Information used in marshalling a given class. This includes cached results of static analysis of the class, and information used in marshalling the class (such as factory methods for objects of that class).

    This information is stored in the form of methods that actually perform marshalling from and unmarshalling into the class in question.

    Author:
    Alex Smith

      • createStandinFor

        protected Standin<T> createStandinFor(T value)
        Creates a standin for the given existing object, which must have an actual type equal to the type this knowledge is about. This will be a composition-based standin unless the object in question happens to be a standin already. The default implementation is slow but general; implementations of this class may wish to override it.

        The main purpose of this method is to allow methods of Standin to be effectively called on a non-standin object (or on an object for which it's unknown whether it's a standin).

        Parameters:
        value - The value to wrap.
        Returns:
        An initially unmanaged and stored-in-self standin wrapping that value (or the value itself if it's already a standin).

      • registerMarshallingException

        public static void registerMarshallingException(ClassKnowledge<?> knowledge)
        Registers an exception to the normal marshalling rules for a given class. The exception is given in the form of a ClassKnowledge object that specifies the new marshalling rules. This has a permanent, global effect; all future marshalling for the given class will be done under the new rules.

        This method is mostly used internally to set up special cases, but can also be called explicitly by a user.

        Parameters:
        knowledge - The exception to add. (The class for which the exception is being made will be inferred from the exception itself.)

      • knowledgeForClass

        protected static <T> ClassKnowledge<T> knowledgeForClass(Class<T> about,
                                                         List<Class<?>> inside)
        Factory method for ClassKnowledge objects. Given a class, checks to see if we already know about it; if we do, returns the existing knowledge; if we don't, does static analysis to determine all the relevant information about the class, then return the information and also stores it for future use. (In other words, this is a kind of memoised constructor that automatically picks an appropriate implementation.)

        This version of the method has an extra parameter to make it safe to call in recursive contexts.

        Type Parameters:
        T - The class to gain knowledge about.
        Parameters:
        about - T.class, given explicitly due to Java's type erasure rules.
        inside - A list of classes which are currently being statically analysed to gain class knowledge about them; this is treated as read-only, and is used to prevent an infinite regress if a class contains a reference to itself.
        Returns:
        A ClassKnowledge object for the existing class; the same object is always returned for the same class.

      • unmarshalsReliably

        public abstract boolean unmarshalsReliably(boolean asField)
        Determines whether the marshalled form of objects of this class can be reliably unmarshalled. Some marshalling forms are unreliable due to not being fully general; the marshalling system will attempt to avoid these forms if possible, via using references at the next level out.

        Sometimes the result changes depending on whether we're talking about a hypothetical object stored in a field of this class, or an actual known class that inherits from this class. As such, this method has a parameter so that the two different options can be distinguished.

        This method should return true if the unmarshalled form of an object is effectively interchangeable with the object itself, and false if they differ or if there's a chance that the marshalled form might not be possible to unmarshal.

        Note that it is not possible in general to avoid unreliable unmarshals, and thus even when reliable marshalling is not possible, class knowledge should make a best-effort attempt at codifying how to marshal an object so that it unmarshals under as many circumstances as possible.

        Parameters:
        asField - Whether we're talking about a hypothetical object stored in a field of this class (true), or a class that inherits from or implements this class (false)
        Returns:
        Whether objects of this class can be reliably unmarshalled.

      • unmarshalsAsCopy

        public abstract boolean unmarshalsAsCopy()
                                  throws UnsupportedOperationException
        Determines whether objects are unmarshalled as a copy of the original object. If this is false, it means that they're unmarshalled to a reference to the original object.

        This method cannot be called if T is an interface (because the answer would depend on the concrete class of the object used to fulfil that interface).

        Returns:
        true if marshalling and unmarshalling an object of the class we know about copies it; false if it instead produces a reference.
        Throws:
        UnsupportedOperationException - If T is an interface
